learning_objectives.description: Describe tests to identify the anions: (a) carbonate, CO₃²⁻, by reaction with dilute acid and then testing for carbon dioxide gas (b) chloride, Cl⁻, bromide, Br⁻, and iodide, I⁻, by acidifying with dilute nitric acid then adding aqueous silver nitrate (c) nitrate, NO₃⁻, by reduction with aluminium foil and aqueous sodium hydroxide and then testing for ammonia gas (d) sulfate, SO₄²⁻, by acidifying with dilute nitric acid then adding aqueous barium nitrate (e) sulfite, SO₃²⁻, by reaction with acidified aqueous potassium manganate(VII)

Describe tests using aqueous sodium hydroxide and aqueous ammonia to identify the aqueous cations: (a) aluminium, Al³⁺ (b) ammonium, NH₄⁺ (c) calcium, Ca²⁺ (d) chromium(III), Cr³⁺ (e) copper(II), Cu²⁺ (f) iron(II), Fe²⁺ (g) iron(III), Fe³⁺ (h) zinc, Zn²⁺

Describe tests to identify the gases: (a) ammonia, NH₃, using damp red litmus paper (b) carbon dioxide, CO₂, using limewater (c) chlorine, Cl₂, using damp litmus paper (d) hydrogen, H₂, using a lighted splint (e) oxygen, O₂, using a glowing splint (f) sulfur dioxide, SO₂, using acidified aqueous potassium manganate(VII)
Describe the use of a flame test to identify the cations: (a) lithium, Li⁺ (b) sodium, Na⁺ (c) potassium, K⁺ (d) calcium, Ca²⁺ (e) barium, Ba²⁺ (f) copper(II), Cu²⁺
